g.text: Sci enti fi c
RepoRtS
www.nature.com/scientificreports
Projected amplification of food
web bioaccumulation of MeHg and
PCBs under climate change in the
Northeastern Pacific
Juan José
Alava
, Andrés M. Cisneros-Montemayor
, U. Rashid
Sumaila
William W. L. Cheung
Climate change increases exposure and bioaccumulation of pollutants in marine organisms,
posing substantial ecophysiological and ecotoxicological risks. Here, we applied a trophodynamic
ecosystem model to examine the bioaccumulation of organic mercury (MeHg) and polychlorinated
biphenyls (PCBs) in a Northeastern Pacific marine food web under climate change. We found largely
heterogeneous sensitivity in climate-pollution impacts between chemicals and trophic groups.
Concentration of MeHg and PCBs in top predators, including resident killer whales, is projected to be
amplified by 8 and 3%, respectively, by 2100 under a high carbon emission scenario (Representative
Concentration Pathway 8.5) relative to a no-climate change control scenario. However, the level of
amplification increases with higher carbon emission scenario for MeHg, but decreases for PCBs. Such
idiosyncratic responses are shaped by the differences in bioaccumulation pathways between MeHg
and PCBs, and the modifications of food web dynamics between different levels of climate change.
Climate-induced pollutant amplification in mid-trophic level predators (Chinook salmon) are projected
to be higher (~10%) than killer whales. Overall, the predicted trophic magnification factor is ten-fold
higher in MeHg than in PCBs under high CO
emissions. This contribution highlights the importance
of understanding the interactions with anthropogenic organic pollutants in assessing climate risks on
marine ecosystems.
While persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and mercury contamination of the marine environment have long
been recognized as global problems
, the effects of climate change in exacerbating pollutant toxicity and
bioaccumulation have recently drawn attention from eco-toxicological research arenas
. MeHg and PCBs
are amongst the most prevalent chemicals in marine food webs, affecting the health of marine organisms
Contaminated seafood poses significant health risks for human consumption, particularly in communities relying
heavily on marine foods as a source of nutrition and socio-economic wellbeing
Ocean warming, deoxygenation and ocean acidification amplify these impacts by increasing the exposure and
bioaccumulation rates for contaminants in marine food webs
. These interactions include phenomena consid-
ered either climate change dominant (i.e., climate change leads to an increase in contaminant exposure/sensitiv-
ity) or contaminant dominant (i.e., contamination leads to an increase in climate change susceptibility)
. Such
climate-pollution interactions are already evidenced in sensitive species and marine ecosystems from the Arctic and
Antarctic regions
. For example, polar bears (
Ursus maritimus
) and sea birds from a warming Arctic exhibit
increasing concentrations of some POPs
and mercury in sea birds
because of changes in their diet composition
and food web structure, and alteration in pollutants exposure and pathways, driven by climate change
. Similarly,
concentrations of dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs) have not decreased in Adelie penguins (
Pygoscelis ade-
liae
) for more than three decades in the western Antarctic Peninsula, where melting glaciers are considered as a
possible recurrent source of DDT contamination to the regional marine food web, upon which penguins rely on
However, information on the extent to which non-Arctic marine ecosystems are affected is limited
